comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Snap (almost)! And please do not be offended by the description of a "mound of swedes" - we had quite an argument as to what these vegetables are called... :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Hi, hi, no offence taken! Actually I thought about that word myself when describing the image in English - but for obvious reasons I found another description (correct for this kind of root vegetable). Thanks for showing us your Irish swedes! :)

/Anna B.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swedish_heritage_board] I wonder if this really is sugar beet, which typically has a more tapered appearance. Lovely image though, and a perfect counterpart to the one from [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture] Yes, the two images really make a good match! :) Actually, I doubted a little about sugar beets too when uploading the image... Today, however, I found a Swedish web site describing the (no longer operative since 1989) sugar beet factory of Karpalund outside Kristianstad in the province of Skåne. The web site shows a photo with almost exactly the same motif and the same kind of cart as in the photo we show here. (The date fits in as well.) It would be great if we could get an opinion from someone with good knowledge about this root crop, so common in southern Sweden since the end of the 19th century. /Anna B.
